Line 298: Line 298:
[[Image:VisualStudio2010.png|thumb|right|Visual Studio 2010 features a new UI developed using [[Windows Presentation Foundation|WPF]]]]
[[Image:VisualStudio2010.png|thumb|right|Visual Studio 2010 features a new UI developed using [[Windows Presentation Foundation|WPF]]]]
â
Visual Studio 2010, codenamed "Hawaii",<ref name="dsource">{{cite web | url = http://www.devsource.com/c/a/Using-VS/Hawaii-A-Visual-Studio-Paradise-for-Developers/ | title = 'Hawaii': A Visual Studio Paradise for Developers? | accessdate = 2008-03-12}}</ref> is under development. A [[Community Technology Preview|community technology preview]] (CTP) version of Visual Studio 2010 was released in 2008 as a pre-installed Virtual Hard Disk containing Windows Server 2008 as the OS. On May 18, 2009, Visual Studio 2010 Beta 1 was released to users of the [[MSDN|Microsoft developer network]], with a public version of the same beta being released on May 20th 2009. This beta is an installable version of the application, unlike the aforementioned CTP which was built into a Virtual Hard Disk.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://blog.garypretty.co.uk/index.php/2009/05/18/visual-studio-2010-beta-1-download-finally-here/ | title = Visual Studio 2010 Beta 1 Finally Here | author = Gary Pretty | accessdate = [[2009-05-18]]}}</ref>
+
Visual Studio 2010, codenamed "Hawaii",<ref name="dsource">{{cite web | url = http://www.devsource.com/c/a/Using-VS/Hawaii-A-Visual-Studio-Paradise-for-Developers/ | title = 'Hawaii': A Visual Studio Paradise for Developers? | accessdate = 2008-03-12}}</ref> is under development. A [[Community Technology Preview|community technology preview]] (CTP) version of Visual Studio 2010 was released in 2008 as a pre-installed Virtual Hard Disk containing Windows Server 2008 as the [[operating system|OS]]. On May 18, 2009, Visual Studio 2010 Beta 1 was released to users of the [[MSDN|Microsoft developer network]], with a public version of the same beta being released on May 20th 2009. This beta is an installable version of the application, unlike the aforementioned CTP which was built into a Virtual Hard Disk.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://blog.garypretty.co.uk/index.php/2009/05/18/visual-studio-2010-beta-1-download-finally-here/ | title = Visual Studio 2010 Beta 1 Finally Here | author = Gary Pretty | accessdate = [[2009-05-18]]}}</ref>
The Visual Studio 2010 [[Integrated development environment|IDE]] has been redesigned which, according to [[Microsoft]], clears the UI organization and "reduces clutter and complexity."<ref name="firstlook"/> The new IDE better supports multiple document windows and floating tool windows,<ref name="firstlook"/> while offering better multi-monitor support. The IDE shell has been rewritten using the [[Windows Presentation Foundation]] (WPF),<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.onedotnetway.com/writing-visual-studio-2010-shell-in-wpf-reflects-confidence/ | title = Writing Visual Studio 2010 shell in WPF Reflects Confidence | publisher = One .NET Way | accessdate = [[2009-04-18]]}}</ref> whereas the internals have been redesigned using [[Managed Extensibility Framework]] (MEF) that offers more extensibility points than previous versions of the IDE that enabled add-ins to modify the behavior of the IDE.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://msmvps.com/blogs/carlosq/archive/2008/10/26/visual-studio-2010-extensibility-moving-beyond-add-ins-and-packages.aspx | title = Visual Studio 2010 Extensibility moving beyond add-ins and packages | author = Carlos Quintero | accessdate = [[2009-04-18]]}}</ref> The new [[multi-paradigm programming language]] [[ML (programming language)|ML]]-variant [[F Sharp programming language|F#]] programming language will be a part of Visual Studio 2010;<ref name="F#">{{cite web | url = http://blogs.msdn.com/dsyme/archive/2008/12/10/fsharp-to-ship-as-part-of-visual-studio-2010.aspx | title = F# to ship as part of Visual Studio 2010 | accessdate = 2008-12-10}}</ref> as will be the [[M (programming language)|M]], the textual modelling language, and ''Quadrant'', the visual model designer, which are a part of the [[Oslo (Microsoft)|Oslo]] initiative.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sdtimes.com/link/32957 | title = Microosft details Oslo's modelling language, tools | publisher = SDTimes | accessdate = [[2009-04-19]]}}</ref>
The Visual Studio 2010 [[Integrated development environment|IDE]] has been redesigned which, according to [[Microsoft]], clears the UI organization and "reduces clutter and complexity."<ref name="firstlook"/> The new IDE better supports multiple document windows and floating tool windows,<ref name="firstlook"/> while offering better multi-monitor support. The IDE shell has been rewritten using the [[Windows Presentation Foundation]] (WPF),<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.onedotnetway.com/writing-visual-studio-2010-shell-in-wpf-reflects-confidence/ | title = Writing Visual Studio 2010 shell in WPF Reflects Confidence | publisher = One .NET Way | accessdate = [[2009-04-18]]}}</ref> whereas the internals have been redesigned using [[Managed Extensibility Framework]] (MEF) that offers more extensibility points than previous versions of the IDE that enabled add-ins to modify the behavior of the IDE.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://msmvps.com/blogs/carlosq/archive/2008/10/26/visual-studio-2010-extensibility-moving-beyond-add-ins-and-packages.aspx | title = Visual Studio 2010 Extensibility moving beyond add-ins and packages | author = Carlos Quintero | accessdate = [[2009-04-18]]}}</ref> The new [[multi-paradigm programming language]] [[ML (programming language)|ML]]-variant [[F Sharp programming language|F#]] programming language will be a part of Visual Studio 2010;<ref name="F#">{{cite web | url = http://blogs.msdn.com/dsyme/archive/2008/12/10/fsharp-to-ship-as-part-of-visual-studio-2010.aspx | title = F# to ship as part of Visual Studio 2010 | accessdate = 2008-12-10}}</ref> as will be the [[M (programming language)|M]], the textual modelling language, and ''Quadrant'', the visual model designer, which are a part of the [[Oslo (Microsoft)|Oslo]] initiative.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sdtimes.com/link/32957 | title = Microosft details Oslo's modelling language, tools | publisher = SDTimes | accessdate = [[2009-04-19]]}}</ref>
